Learning to sew is for a woman equivalent to writing for a man. Spectacular Ludovico Dolce. What happened? Almost all the convents needed the money they obtained from the sales of the lace and other sewing they did. Even in one of the richest and most aristocratic convents in Venice, which was the convent of Santa Caria, they needed, that is, they needed that money. And a lot is preserved there, apart from all the texts she wrote, some of which she published, some of which she did not, but there are also many letters of the archangel sun, and in many of them she constantly describes the laces of the nuns and all the negotiations around all this. For example, to Isabetta Piccolomini Scarpi she assures her that her order, although it is driving her crazy, will be ready in time. She takes it upon herself to reassure all the clients. In another letter she informs Marchesa Renata di Claramonte that there is going to be a delay in her commission because, she says, the nuns who were committed to the work are ill or have left the monastery. Of course, she had to manage the staff. Also to Madame de Ano, wife of the French ambassador, she says that the lace she ordered will cost no less than 60 ducats for Braccio. Well, it's all logistics, it's all networking and it's also all industrial espionage, because during her time in the office she makes sure that no detail of what is being made out there and what needs to be produced escapes her attention. She is Inditex.

text_en: I will tell you that without reaching the levels of Inditex, our Santa Teresa and Maria de San Jose, the Carmelite Prioress of Seville, spent some period immersed in a quite interesting transfer that I did not know. I have investigated for this episode of fabrics between Madrid and Seville, Maria de San Jose what she did was that she sent luxurious fabrics from Seville that Teresa tried to sell and distribute in cities like Toledo to support works and foundations. It didn't always work out. For example, surprise. On May 28, 1577 she wrote a letter to Maria de San Jose, a little overwhelmed and bad luck we have had with this canvas of your reverence that has been taken to half Toledo of houses and monasteries and has not been able to sell because everyone is too much to give four reals for it and give it for less seems to be conscience, I do not know what we make of it. Go to your reverence what you want to do. I love when St. Teresa says give it for less seems to be conscience, that does not cheapen anything. St. Teresa is spectacular. Let's see, I'm going to say it because we do not say it for a long time, which is that there is nothing that is happening to us that had not already happened to a nun in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
